dialogues.line: Ay, but, I fear me, in another sense. What love, thinkst thou, I sue so much to get?

dialogues.speaker: Lady Grey
dialogues.line: My love till death, my humble thanks, my prayers; That love which virtue begs, and virtue grants.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: No, by my troth, I did not mean such love.

dialogues.speaker: Lady Grey
dialogues.line: Why, then, you mean not as I thought you did.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: But now you partly may perceive my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Lady Grey
dialogues.line: My mind will never grant what I perceive Your Highness aims at, if I aim aright.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.

dialogues.speaker: Lady Grey
dialogues.line: To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Why, then thou shalt not have thy husband's lands.

dialogues.speaker: Lady Grey
dialogues.line: Why, then mine honesty shall be my dower, For by that loss I will not purchase them.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Therein thou wrong'st thy children mightily.

dialogues.speaker: Lady Grey
dialogues.line: Herein your Highness wrongs both them and me. But, mighty lord, this merry inclination Accords not with the sadness of my suit. Please you dismiss me either with ay or no.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Ay, if thou wilt say ay to my request; No, if thou dost say no to my demand.

dialogues.speaker: Lady Grey
dialogues.line: Then no, my lord. My suit is at an end.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: The widow likes him not, she knits her brows.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: He is the bluntest wooer in Christendom.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Her looks doth argue her replete with modesty; Her words doth show her wit incomparable; All her perfections challenge sovereignty. One way or other, she is for a king, And she shall be my love, or else my queen.- Say that King Edward take thee for his queen?

dialogues.speaker: Lady Grey
dialogues.line: 'Tis better said than done, my gracious lord. I am a subject fit to jest withal, But far unfit to be a sovereign.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Sweet widow, by my state I swear to thee, I speak no more than what my soul intends; And that is to enjoy thee for my love.

dialogues.speaker: Lady Grey
dialogues.line: And that is more than I will yield unto. I know I am too mean to be your queen, And yet too good to be your concubine.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: You cavil, widow; I did mean my queen.

dialogues.speaker: Lady Grey
dialogues.line: 'Twill grieve your Grace my sons should call you father.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: No more than when my daughters call thee mother. Thou art a widow, and thou hast some children; And, by God's mother, I, being but a bachelor, Have other some. Why, 'tis a happy thing To be the father unto many sons. Answer no more, for thou shalt be my queen.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: The ghostly father now hath done his shrift.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: When he was made a shriver, 'twas for shift.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Brothers, you muse what chat we two have had. Richard and George come forward.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: The widow likes it not, for she looks very sad.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: You'd think it strange if I should marry her.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: To whom, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Why, Clarence, to myself.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: That would be ten days' wonder at the least.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: That's a day longer than a wonder lasts.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: By so much is the wonder in extremes.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Well, jest on, brothers. I can tell you both Her suit is granted for her husband's lands.

dialogues.speaker: Nobleman
dialogues.line: My gracious lord, Henry your foe is taken, And brought your prisoner to your palace gate.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: See that he be conveyed unto the Tower. And go we, brothers, to the man that took him, To question of his apprehension. Widow, go you along. Lords, use her honourably.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Ay, Edward will use women honourably. Would he were wasted, marrow, bones, and all, That from his loins no hopeful branch may spring, To cross me from the golden time I look for! And yet, between my soul's desire and me- The lustful Edward's title buried- Is Clarence, Henry, and his son young Edward, And all the unlooked-for issue of their bodies, To take their rooms ere I can place myself. A cold premeditation for my purpose! Why then I do but dream on sovereignty; Like one that stands upon a promontory And spies a far-off shore where he would tread, Wishing his foot were equal with his eye, And chides the sea that sunders him from thence, Saying he'll lade it dry to have his way. So do I wish the crown, being so far off, And so I chide the means that keeps me from it; And so I say I'll cut the causes off, Flattering me with impossibilities. My eye's too quick, my heart o'erweens too much, Unless my hand and strength could equal them. Well, say there is no kingdom then for Richard, What other pleasure can the world afford? I'll make my heaven in a lady's lap, And deck my body in gay ornaments, And 'witch sweet ladies with my words and looks. O miserable thought, and more unlikely Than to accomplish twenty golden crowns. Why, Love forswore me in my mother's womb, And, for I should not deal in her soft laws, She did corrupt frail Nature with some bribe To shrink mine arm up like a withered shrub; To make an envious mountain on my back, Where sits Deformity to mock my body; To shape my legs of an unequal size; To disproportion me in every part, Like to a chaos, or an unlicked bear-whelp That carries no impression like the dam. And am I then a man to be beloved? O monstrous fault to harbour such a thought! Then, since this earth affords no joy to me But to command, to check, to o'erbear such As are of better person than myself, I'll make my heaven to dream upon the crown, And, whiles I live, t' account this world but hell Until my misshaped trunk that bear this head Be round impaled with a glorious crown. And yet I know not how to get the crown, For many lives stand between me and home; And I, like one lost in a thorny wood, That rents the thorns, and is rent with the thorns, Seeking a way, and straying from the way, Not knowing how to find the open air, But toiling desperately to find it out, Torment myself to catch the English crown. And from that torment I will free myself, Or hew my way out with a bloody axe. Why, I can smile, and murder while I smile, And cry "Content!" to that which grieves my heart, And wet my cheeks with artificial tears, And frame my face to all occasions. I'll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall, I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk; I'll play the orator as well as Nestor, Deceive more slyly than Ulysses could, And, like a Sinon, take another Troy. I can add colours to the chameleon, Change shapes with Proteus for advantages, And set the murderous Machiavel to school. Can I do this, and cannot get a crown? Tut, were it farther off, I'll pluck it down.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Fair Queen of England, worthy Margaret, Sit down with us. It ill befits thy state And birth that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth sit.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: No, mighty King of France. Now Margaret Must strike her sail and learn awhile to serve Where kings command. I was, I must confess, Great Albion's queen in former golden days; But now mischance hath trod my title down And with dishonour laid me on the ground, Where I must take like seat unto my fortune And to my humble seat conform myself.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Why, say, fair queen, whence springs this deep despair?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: From such a cause as fills mine eyes with tears And stops my tongue, while heart is drowned in cares.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Whate'er it be, be thou still like thyself, And sit thee by our side. Yield not thy neck To Fortune's yoke, but let thy dauntless mind Still ride in triumph over all mischance. Be plain, Queen Margaret, and tell thy grief; It shall be eased if France can yield relief.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Those gracious words revive my drooping thoughts And give my tongue-tied sorrows leave to speak. Now, therefore, be it known to noble Lewis That Henry, sole possessor of my love, Is, of a king, become a banished man And forced to live in Scotland a forlorn; While proud ambitious Edward, Duke of York, Usurps the regal title and the seat Of England's true-anointed lawful king. This is the cause that I, poor Margaret, With this my son, Prince Edward, Henry's heir, Am come to crave thy just and lawful aid; And if thou fail us, all our hope is done. Scotland hath will to help, but cannot help; Our people and our peers are both misled, Our treasure seized, our soldiers put to flight, And, as thou seest, ourselves in heavy plight.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Renowned queen, with patience calm the storm While we bethink a means to break it off.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: The more we stay, the stronger grows our foe.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: The more I stay, the more I'll succour thee.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: O, but impatience waiteth on true sorrow. And see where comes the breeder of my sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: What's he approacheth boldly to our presence?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Our Earl of Warwick, Edward's greatest friend.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Welcome, brave Warwick. What brings thee to France?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Ay, now begins a second storm to rise, For this is he that moves both wind and tide.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: From worthy Edward, king of Albion, My lord and sovereign, and thy vowed friend, I come, in kindness and unfeigned love, First, to do greetings to thy royal person, And then to crave a league of amity, And lastly, to confirm that amity With nuptial knot, if thou vouchsafe to grant That virtuous Lady Bona, thy fair sister, To England's king in lawful marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: If that go forward, Henry's hope is done.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: And, gracious madam, in our king's behalf, I am commanded, with your leave and favour, Humbly to kiss your hand, and with my tongue To tell the passion of my sovereign's heart, Where fame, late entering at his heedful ears, Hath placed thy beauty's image and thy virtue.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: King Lewis and Lady Bona, hear me speak Before you answer Warwick. His demand Springs not from Edward's well-meant honest love, But from deceit, bred by necessity; For how can tyrants safely govern home Unless abroad they purchase great alliance? To prove him tyrant this reason may suffice, That Henry liveth still; but were he dead, Yet here Prince Edward stands, King Henry's son. Look therefore, Lewis, that by this league and marriage Thou draw not on thy danger and dishonour; For though usurpers sway the rule awhile, Yet heavens are just, and time suppresseth wrongs.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Injurious Margaret!

dialogues.speaker: Prince Edward
dialogues.line: And why not Queen?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Because thy father Henry did usurp, And thou no more art prince than she is queen.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: Then Warwick disannuls great John of Gaunt, Which did subdue the greatest part of Spain; And after John of Gaunt, Henry the Fourth, Whose wisdom was a mirror to the wisest; And after that wise prince, Henry the Fifth, Who by his prowess conquered all France. From these our Henry lineally descends.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Oxford, how haps it in this smooth discourse You told not how Henry the Sixth hath lost All that which Henry the Fifth had gotten? Methinks these peers of France should smile at that. But for the rest: you tell a pedigree Of threescore and two years, a silly time To make prescription for a kingdom's worth.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: Why, Warwick, canst thou speak against thy liege, Whom thou obeyed'st thirty and six years, And not bewray thy treason with a blush?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Can Oxford, that did ever fence the right, Now buckler falsehood with a pedigree? For shame! Leave Henry, and call Edward king.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: Call him my king by whose injurious doom My elder brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere, Was done to death? And more than so, my father, Even in the downfall of his mellowed years, When nature brought him to the door of death? No, Warwick, no; while life upholds this arm, This arm upholds the house of Lancaster.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: And I the house of York.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford, Vouchsafe at our request to stand aside While I use further conference with Warwick.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Heavens grant that Warwick's words bewitch him not!

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Now, Warwick, tell me, even upon thy conscience, Is Edward your true king? For I were loath To link with him that were not lawful chosen.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: But is he gracious in the people's eye?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: The more that Henry was unfortunate.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Then further, all dissembling set aside, Tell me for truth the measure of his love Unto our sister Bona.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Such it seems As may beseem a monarch like himself. Myself have often heard him say and swear That this his love was an eternal plant, Whereof the root was fixed in virtue's ground, The leaves and fruit maintained with beauty's sun, Exempt from envy, but not from disdain, Unless the Lady Bona quit his pain.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Now, sister, let us hear your firm resolve.

dialogues.speaker: Bona
dialogues.line: Your grant or your denial shall be mine.  Yet I confess that often ere this day, When I have heard your king's desert recounted, Mine ear hath tempted judgment to desire.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Then, Warwick, thus: our sister shall be Edward's. And now forthwith shall articles be drawn Touching the jointure that your king must make, Which with her dowry shall be counterpoised. Draw near, Queen Margaret, and be a witness That Bona shall be wife to the English king.

dialogues.speaker: Prince Edward
dialogues.line: To Edward, but not to the English king.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Deceitful Warwick, it was thy device By this alliance to make void my suit. Before thy coming Lewis was Henry's friend.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: And still is friend to him and Margaret. But if your title to the crown be weak, As may appear by Edward's good success, Then 'tis but reason that I be released From giving aid which late I promised. Yet shall you have all kindness at my hand That your estate requires and mine can yield.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Henry now lives in Scotland, at his ease, Where, having nothing, nothing can he lose. And as for you yourself, our quondam queen, You have a father able to maintain you, And better 'twere you troubled him than France.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Peace, impudent and shameless Warwick, Proud setter up and puller down of kings! I will not hence till with my talk and tears, Both full of truth, I make King Lewis behold Thy sly conveyance and thy lord's false love; For both of you are birds of selfsame feather.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Warwick, this is some post to us or thee.

dialogues.speaker: Post
dialogues.line: My lord ambassador, these letters are for you. Sent from your brother, Marquess Montague. These from our king unto your Majesty. And, madam, these for you, from whom I know not.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: I like it well that our fair Queen and mistress Smiles at her news while Warwick frowns at his.

dialogues.speaker: Prince Edward
dialogues.line: Nay, mark how Lewis stamps as he were nettled. I hope all's for the best.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Warwick, what are thy news? And yours, fair Queen?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Mine, such as fill my heart with unhoped joys.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Mine, full of sorrow and heart's discontent.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: What, has your king married the Lady Grey, And now, to soothe your forgery and his, Sends me a paper to persuade me patience? Is this th' alliance that he seeks with France? Dare he presume to scorn us in this manner?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: I told your majesty as much before; This proveth Edward's love and Warwick's honesty.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: King Lewis, I here protest in sight of heaven, And by the hope I have of heavenly bliss, That I am clear from this misdeed of Edward's- No more my king, for he dishonours me, But most himself, if he could see his shame. Did I forget that by the house of York My father came untimely to his death? Did I let pass th' abuse done to my niece? Did I impale him with the regal crown? Did I put Henry from his native right? And am I guerdoned at the last with shame? Shame on himself, for my desert is honour; And to repair my honour lost for him, I here renounce him and return to Henry. My noble Queen, let former grudges pass, And henceforth I am thy true servitor. I will revenge his wrong to Lady Bona, And replant Henry in his former state.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Warwick, these words have turned my hate to love; And I forgive and quite forget old faults, And joy that thou becom'st King Henry's friend.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: So much his friend, ay, his unfeigned friend, That if King Lewis vouchsafe to furnish us With some few bands of chosen soldiers, I'll undertake to land them on our coast And force the tyrant from his seat by war. 'Tis not his new-made bride shall succour him; And as for Clarence, as my letters tell me, He's very likely now to fall from him For matching more for wanton lust than honour, Or than for strength and safety of our country.

dialogues.speaker: Bona
dialogues.line: Dear brother, how shall Bona be revenged But by thy help to this distressed queen?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Renowned prince, how shall poor Henry live Unless thou rescue him from foul despair?

dialogues.speaker: Bona
dialogues.line: My quarrel and this English queen's are one.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: And mine, fair Lady Bona, joins with yours.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: And mine with hers, and thine, and Margaret's. Therefore, at last I firmly am resolved You shall have aid.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Let me give humble thanks for all at once.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Then, England's messenger, return in post And tell false Edward, thy supposed king, That Lewis of France is sending over maskers To revel it with him and his new bride. Thou seest what's past; go fear thy king withal.

dialogues.speaker: Bona
dialogues.line: Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly, I'll wear the willow garland for his sake.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Tell him my mourning weeds are laid aside, And I am ready to put armour on.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong, And therefore I'll uncrown him ere 't be long. There's thy reward; be gone.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: But, Warwick, Thou and Oxford, with five thousand men, Shall cross the seas and bid false Edward battle; And, as occasion serves, this noble Queen And prince shall follow with a fresh supply. Yet, ere thou go, but answer me one doubt: What pledge have we of thy firm loyalty?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: This shall assure my constant loyalty: That if our Queen and this young prince agree, I'll join mine eldest daughter and my joy To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Yes, I agree, and thank you for your motion. Son Edward, she is fair and virtuous, Therefore delay not, give thy hand to Warwick, And with thy hand thy faith irrevocable That only Warwick's daughter shall be thine.

dialogues.speaker: Prince Edward
dialogues.line: Yes, I accept her, for she well deserves it; And here, to pledge my vow, I give my hand.

dialogues.speaker: King Lewis
dialogues.line: Why stay we now? These soldiers shall be levied, And thou, Lord Bourbon, our High Admiral, Shall waft them over with our royal fleet. I long till Edward fall by war's mischance For mocking marriage with a dame of France.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: I came from Edward as ambassador, But I return his sworn and mortal foe. Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me, But dreadful war shall answer his demand. Had he none else to make a stale but me? Then none but I shall turn his jest to sorrow. I was the chief that raised him to the crown, And I'll be chief to bring him down again: Not that I pity Henry's misery, But seek revenge on Edward's mockery.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Now tell me, brother Clarence, what think you Of this new marriage with the Lady Grey? Hath not our brother made a worthy choice?

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: Alas, you know 'tis far from hence to France! How could he stay till Warwick made return?

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: My lords, forbear this talk; here comes the King. Flourish. Enter King Edward, attended; Lady Grey as Queen Elizabeth; Pembroke, Stafford, Hastings and others. Four stand on one side, and four on the other.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: And his well-chosen bride.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: I mind to tell him plainly what I think.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Now, brother of Clarence, how like you our choice, That you stand pensive as half malcontent?

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: As well as Lewis of France or the Earl of Warwick, Which are so weak of courage and in judgment That they'll take no offence at our abuse.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Suppose they take offence without a cause, They are but Lewis and Warwick; I am Edward, Your King and Warwick's, and must have my will.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: And shall have your will, because our King. Yet hasty marriage seldom proveth well.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Yea, brother Richard, are you offended too?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Not I. No, God forbid that I should wish them severed Whom God hath joined together. Ay, and 'twere pity To sunder them that yoke so well together.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Setting your scorns and your mislike aside, Tell me some reason why the Lady Grey Should not become my wife and England's queen. And you too, Somerset and Montague, Speak freely what you think.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: Then this is mine opinion: that King Lewis Becomes your enemy for mocking him About the marriage of the Lady Bona.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: And Warwick, doing what you gave in charge, Is now dishonoured by this new marriage.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: What if both Lewis and Warwick be appeased By such invention as I can devise?

dialogues.speaker: Montague
dialogues.line: Yet to have joined with France in such alliance Would more have strengthened this our commonwealth 'Gainst foreign storms than any home-bred marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Why, knows not Montague that of itself England is safe, if true within itself?

dialogues.speaker: Montague
dialogues.line: But the safer when 'tis backed with France.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: 'Tis better using France than trusting France. Let us be backed with God and with the seas Which He hath giv'n for fence impregnable, And with their helps only defend ourselves. In them and in ourselves our safety lies.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: For this one speech Lord Hastings well deserves To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Ay, what of that? It was my will and grant; And for this once my will shall stand for law.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: And yet, methinks, your Grace hath not done well To give the heir and daughter of Lord Scales Unto the brother of your loving bride. She better would have fitted me or Clarence; But in your bride you bury brotherhood.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: Or else you would not have bestowed the heir Of the Lord Bonville on your new wife's son, And leave your brothers to go speed elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Alas, poor Clarence, is it for a wife That thou art malcontent? I will provide thee.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: In choosing for yourself you showed your judgment, Which being shallow, you shall give me leave To play the broker in mine own behalf; And to that end I shortly mind to leave you.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Leave me or tarry, Edward will be king, And not be tied unto his brother's will.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: My lords, before it pleased his Majesty To raise my state to title of a queen, Do me but right, and you must all confess That I was not ignoble of descent, And meaner than myself have had like fortune. But as this title honours me and mine, So your dislikes, to whom I would be pleasing, Doth cloud my joys with danger and with sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: My love, forbear to fawn upon their frowns. What danger or what sorrow can befall thee So long as Edward is thy constant friend And their true sovereign, whom they must obey? Nay, whom they shall obey, and love thee too, Unless they seek for hatred at my hands; Which if they do, yet will I keep thee safe, And they shall feel the vengeance of my wrath.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I hear, yet say not much, but think the more.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Now, messenger, what letters or what news From France?

dialogues.speaker: Post
dialogues.line: My sovereign liege, no letters, and few words, But such as I, without your special pardon, Dare not relate.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Go to, we pardon thee. Therefore, in brief, Tell me their words as near as thou canst guess them. What answer makes King Lewis unto our letters?

dialogues.speaker: Post
dialogues.line: At my depart these were his very words: "Go tell false Edward, thy supposed king, That Lewis of France is sending over maskers To revel it with him and his new bride."

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Is Lewis so brave? Belike he thinks me Henry. But what said Lady Bona to my marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Post
dialogues.line: These were her words, uttered with mild disdain: "Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly, I'll wear the willow garland for his sake."

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: I blame not her; she could say little less; She had the wrong. But what said Henry's queen? For I have heard that she was there in place.

dialogues.speaker: Post
dialogues.line: "Tell him," quoth she "my mourning weeds are done, And I am ready to put armour on."

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Belike she minds to play the Amazon. But what said Warwick to these injuries?

dialogues.speaker: Post
dialogues.line: He, more incensed against your Majesty Than all the rest, discharged me with these words: "Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong, And therefore I'll uncrown him ere 't be long."

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Ha! Durst the traitor breathe out so proud words? Well, I will arm me, being thus forewarned. They shall have wars and pay for their presumption. But say, is Warwick friends with Margaret?

dialogues.speaker: Post
dialogues.line: Ay, gracious sovereign, they are so linked in friendship That young Prince Edward marries Warwick's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: Belike the elder; Clarence will have the younger. Now, brother king, farewell, and sit you fast, For I will hence to Warwick's other daughter; That, though I want a kingdom, yet in marriage I may not prove inferior to yourself. You that love me and Warwick, follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Not I. My thoughts aim at a further matter; I stay not for the love of Edward, but the crown.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwick! Yet am I armed against the worst can happen, And haste is needful in this desperate case. Pembroke and Stafford, you in our behalf Go levy men and make prepare for war; They are already, or quickly will be, landed. Myself in person will straight follow you. But, ere I go, Hastings and Montague, Resolve my doubt. You twain, of all the rest, Are near to Warwick by blood and by alliance. Tell me if you love Warwick more than me. If it be so, then both depart to him. I rather wish you foes than hollow friends. But if you mind to hold your true obedience, Give me assurance with some friendly vow, That I may never have you in suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Montague
dialogues.line: So God help Montague as he proves true!

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: And Hastings as he favours Edward's cause!

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Now, brother Richard, will you stand by us?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Ay, in despite of all that shall withstand you.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Why, so! Then am I sure of victory. Now, therefore, let us hence, and lose no hour Till we meet Warwick with his foreign power.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Trust me, my lord, all hitherto goes well; The common people by numbers swarm to us. Enter George (Duke of Clarence) and Somerset. But see where Somerset and Clarence comes. Speak suddenly, my lords: are we all friends?

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: Fear not that, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Then, gentle Clarence, welcome unto Warwick; And welcome, Somerset. I hold it cowardice To rest mistrustful where a noble heart Hath pawned an open hand in sign of love; Else might I think that Clarence, Edward's brother, Were but a feigned friend to our proceedings. But welcome, sweet Clarence; my daughter shall be thine. And now what rests but, in night's coverture, Thy brother being carelessly encamped, His soldiers lurking in the towns about, And but attended by a simple guard, We may surprise and take him at our pleasure? Our scouts have found the adventure very easy; That, as Ulysses and stout Diomede With sleight and manhood stole to Rhesus' tents, And brought from thence the Thracian fatal steeds, So we, well covered with the night's black mantle, At unawares may beat down Edward's guard, And seize himself. I say not, slaughter him, For I intend but only to surprise him. You that will follow me to this attempt, Applaud the name of Henry with your leader. Why then, let's on our way in silent sort, For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George!

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: This is his tent; and see where stand his guard. Courage, my masters! Honour now or never! But follow me, and Edward shall be ours. 1 WATCHMAN. Who goes there? 2 WATCHMAN. Stay, or thou diest.  The drum playing and trumpet sounding, enter Warwick, Somerset, and the rest, bringing the King out in his gown, sitting in a chair. Richard (Duke of Gloucester) and Hastings fly over the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: What are they that fly there?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Richard and Hastings. Let them go. Here is the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: The Duke? Why, Warwick, when we parted, Thou call'dst me king?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Ay, but the case is altered. When you disgraced me in my embassade, Then I degraded you from being king, And come now to create you Duke of York. Alas, how should you govern any kingdom That know not how to use ambassadors, Nor how to be contented with one wife, Nor how to use your brothers brotherly, Nor how to study for the people's welfare, Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies?

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Yea, brother of Clarence, art thou here too? Nay, then I see that Edward needs must down. Yet, Warwick, in despite of all mischance Of thee thyself and all thy complices, Edward will always bear himself as king. Though Fortune's malice overthrow my state, My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Then for his mind be Edward England's king; But Henry now shall wear the English crown And be true king indeed, thou but the shadow. My lord of Somerset, at my request, See that forthwith Duke Edward be conveyed Unto my brother, Archbishop of York. When I have fought with Pembroke and his fellows, I'll follow you and tell what answer Lewis and the Lady Bona send to him. Now, for a while farewell, good Duke of York.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: What fates impose, that men must needs abide; It boots not to resist both wind and tide.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: What now remains, my lords, for us to do, But march to London with our soldiers?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Ay, that's the first thing that we have to do, To free King Henry from imprisonment And see him seated in the regal throne.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: Madam, what makes you in this sudden change?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Why, brother Rivers, are you yet to learn What late misfortune is befall'n King Edward?

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: What, loss of some pitched battle against Warwick?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: No, but the loss of his own royal person.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: Then is my sovereign slain?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Ay, almost slain, for he is taken prisoner, Either betrayed by falsehood of his guard Or by his foe surprised at unawares; And, as I further have to understand, Is new committed to the Bishop of York, Fell Warwick's brother and by that our foe.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: These news, I must confess, are full of grief; Yet, gracious madam, bear it as you may. Warwick may lose that now hath won the day.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Till then, fair hope must hinder life's decay; And I the rather wean me from despair For love of Edward's offspring in my womb. This is it that makes me bridle passion And bear with mildness my misfortune's cross, Ay, ay, for this I draw in many a tear And stop the rising of blood-sucking sighs, Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown King Edward's fruit, true heir to th' English crown.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: But, madam, where is Warwick then become?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: I am informed that he comes towards London To set the crown once more on Henry's head. Guess thou the rest: King Edward's friends must down. But to prevent the tyrant's violence- For trust not him that hath once broken faith- I'll hence forthwith unto the sanctuary To save at least the heir of Edward's right. There shall I rest secure from force and fraud. Come, therefore, let us fly while we may fly. If Warwick take us, we are sure to die.

scenes.location: A park near Middleham Castle in Yorkshire

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Now, my Lord Hastings and Sir William Stanley, Leave off to wonder why I drew you hither Into this chiefest thicket of the park. Thus stands the case: you know our King, my brother, Is prisoner to the Bishop here, at whose hands He hath good usage and great liberty, And often but attended with weak guard, Comes hunting this way to disport himself. I have advertised him by secret means That if about this hour he make this way, Under the colour of his usual game, He shall here find his friends with horse and men To set him free from his captivity.

dialogues.speaker: Huntsman
dialogues.line: This way, my lord, for this way lies the game.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Nay, this way, man. See where the huntsmen stand. Now, brother of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, and the rest, Stand you thus close to steal the Bishop's deer?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Brother, the time and case requireth haste; Your horse stands ready at the park corner.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: But whither shall we then?

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: To Lynn, my lord, and shipped from thence to Flanders.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Well guessed, believe me, for that was my meaning.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Stanley, I will requite thy forwardness.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: But wherefore stay we? 'Tis no time to talk.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Huntsman, what sayst thou? Wilt thou go along?

dialogues.speaker: Huntsman
dialogues.line: Better do so than tarry and be hanged.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Come then, away! Let's ha' no more ado.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Bishop, farewell; shield thee from Warwick's frown, And pray that I may repossess the crown.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Master Lieutenant, now that God and friends Have shaken Edward from the regal seat And turned my captive state to liberty, My fear to hope, my sorrows unto joys, At our enlargement what are thy due fees?

dialogues.speaker: Lieutenant
dialogues.line: Subjects may challenge nothing of their sovereigns; But if an humble prayer may prevail, I then crave pardon of your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: For what, lieutenant? For well using me? Nay, be thou sure I'll well requite thy kindness, For that it made my imprisonment a pleasure; Ay, such a pleasure as incaged birds Conceive when, after many moody thoughts, At last by notes of household harmony They quite forget their loss of liberty. But, Warwick, after God thou sett'st me free, And chiefly therefore I thank God and thee; He was the author, thou the instrument. Therefore, that I may conquer Fortune's spite, By living low where Fortune cannot hurt me, And that the people of this blessed land May not be punished with my thwarting stars, Warwick, although my head still wear the crown, I here resign my government to thee, For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Your Grace hath still been famed for virtuous, And now may seem as wise as virtuous By spying and avoiding Fortune's malice, For few men rightly temper with the stars; Yet in this one thing let me blame your Grace, For choosing me when Clarence is in place.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: No, Warwick, thou art worthy of the sway, To whom the heavens in thy nativity Adjudged an olive branch and laurel crown, As likely to be blest in peace and war; And therefore I yield thee my free consent.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: And I choose Clarence only for Protector.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Warwick and Clarence, give me both your hands. Now join your hands, and with your hands your hearts, That no dissension hinder government. I make you both Protectors of this land, While I myself will lead a private life And in devotion spend my latter days, To sin's rebuke and my Creator's praise.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: What answers Clarence to his sovereign's will?

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: That he consents, if Warwick yield consent, For on thy fortune I repose myself.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Why, then, though loath, yet I must be content. We'll yoke together, like a double shadow To Henry's body, and supply his place; I mean, in bearing weight of government, While he enjoys the honour and his ease. And, Clarence, now then it is more than needful Forthwith that Edward be pronounced a traitor And all his lands and goods be confiscate.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: What else? And that succession be determined.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Ay, therein Clarence shall not want his part.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: But with the first of all your chief affairs Let me entreat-for I command no more- That Margaret your Queen and my son Edward Be sent for to return from France with speed; For till I see them here, by doubtful fear My joy of liberty is half eclipsed.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: It shall be done, my sovereign, with all speed.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: My Lord of Somerset, what youth is that Of whom you seem to have so tender care?

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: My liege, it is young Henry, Earl of Richmond.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Come hither, England's hope. If secret powers Suggest but truth to my divining thoughts, This pretty lad will prove our country's bliss. His looks are full of peaceful majesty, His head by nature framed to wear a crown, His hand to wield a sceptre, and himself Likely in time to bless a regal throne. Make much of him, my lords, for this is he Must help you more than you are hurt by me.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: What news, my friend?

dialogues.speaker: Post
dialogues.line: That Edward is escaped from your brother And fled, as he hears since, to Burgundy.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Unsavoury news! But how made he escape?

dialogues.speaker: Post
dialogues.line: He was conveyed by Richard, Duke of Gloucester And the Lord Hastings, who attended him In secret ambush on the forest side And from the Bishop's huntsmen rescued him, For hunting was his daily exercise.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: My brother was too careless of his charge. But let us hence, my sovereign, to provide A salve for any sore that may betide.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: My lord, I like not of this flight of Edward's, For doubtless Burgundy will yield him help, And we shall have more wars before 't be long. As Henry's late presaging prophecy Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond, So doth my heart misgive me, in these conflicts What may befall him, to his harm and ours. Therefore, Lord Oxford, to prevent the worst, Forthwith we'll send him hence to Brittany Till storms be past of civil enmity.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: Ay, for if Edward repossess the crown, 'Tis like that Richmond with the rest shall down.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: It shall be so. He shall to Brittany. Come therefore, let's about it speedily.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Now, brother Richard, Lord Hastings, and the rest, Yet thus far Fortune maketh us amends, And says that once more I shall interchange My waned state for Henry's regal crown. Well have we passed and now repassed the seas, And brought desired help from Burgundy. What then remains, we being thus arrived From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York, But that we enter as into our dukedom?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: The gates made fast! Brother, I like not this; For many men that stumble at the threshold Are well foretold that danger lurks within.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Tush, man, abodements must not now affright us. By fair or foul means we must enter in, For hither will our friends repair to us.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: My liege, I'll knock once more to summon them.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: My lords, we were forewarned of your coming And shut the gates for safety of ourselves, For now we owe allegiance unto Henry.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: But, master Mayor, if Henry be your king, Yet Edward, at the least, is Duke of York.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: True, my good lord, I know you for no less.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Why, and I challenge nothing but my dukedom, As being well content with that alone.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: But when the fox hath once got in his nose, He'll soon find means to make the body follow.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Why, master Mayor, why stand you in a doubt? Open the gates; we are King Henry's friends.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: Ay, say you so? The gates shall then be opened.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: A wise, stout captain, and soon persuaded.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: The good old man would fain that all were well, So 'twere not long of him; but, being entered, I doubt not, I, but we shall soon persuade Both him and all his brothers unto reason.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: So, master Mayor, these gates must not be shut But in the night or in the time of war. What, fear not, man, but yield me up the keys; For Edward will defend the town and thee And all those friends that deign to follow me. March. Enter Montgomery with drum and Soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Brother, this is Sir John Montgomery, Our trusty friend unless I be deceived.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Welcome, Sir John! But why come you in arms?

dialogues.speaker: Montgomery
dialogues.line: To help King Edward in his time of storm, As every loyal subject ought to do.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Thanks, good Montgomery; but we now forget Our title to the crown, and only claim Our dukedom till God please to send the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Montgomery
dialogues.line: Then fare you well, for I will hence again. I came to serve a king, and not a duke. Drummer, strike up, and let us march away.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Nay, stay, Sir John, a while, and we'll debate By what safe means the crown may be recovered.

dialogues.speaker: Montgomery
dialogues.line: What talk you of debating? In few words, If you'll not here proclaim yourself our king, I'll leave you to your fortune and be gone To keep them back that come to succour you. Why shall we fight if you pretend no title?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Why, brother, wherefore stand you on nice points?

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: When we grow stronger, then we'll make our claim. Till then 'tis wisdom to conceal our meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Away with scrupulous wit! Now arms must rule.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: And fearless minds climb soonest unto crowns. Brother, we will proclaim you out of hand; The bruit thereof will bring you many friends.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Then be it as you will; for 'tis my right, And Henry but usurps the diadem.

dialogues.speaker: Montgomery
dialogues.line: Ay, now my sovereign speaketh like himself, And now will I be Edward's champion.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Sound, trumpet; Edward shall be here proclaimed. Come, fellow soldier, make thou proclamation.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: _Edward the Fourth, by the Grace of God, King of England and France, and Lord of Ireland, etc._

dialogues.speaker: Montgomery
dialogues.line: And whoso'er gainsays King Edward's right, By this I challenge him to single fight.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Long live Edward the Fourth!

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Thanks, brave Montgomery, and thanks unto you all. If Fortune serve me, I'll requite this kindness. Now for this night let's harbour here in York, And when the morning sun shall raise his car Above the border of this horizon We'll forward towards Warwick and his mates; For well I wot that Henry is no soldier. Ah, froward Clarence, how evil it beseems thee To flatter Henry and forsake thy brother! Yet, as we may, we'll meet both thee and Warwick. Come on, brave soldiers; doubt not of the day, And, that once gotten, doubt not of large pay.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: What counsel, lords? Edward from Belgia, With hasty Germans and blunt Hollanders, Hath passed in safety through the Narrow Seas, And with his troops doth march amain to London; And many giddy people flock to him.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Let's levy men and beat him back again.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: A little fire is quickly trodden out, Which, being suffered, rivers cannot quench.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: In Warwickshire I have true-hearted friends, Not mutinous in peace, yet bold in war. Those will I muster up; and thou, son Clarence, Shalt stir up in Suffolk, Norfolk, and in Kent The knights and gentlemen to come with thee. Thou, brother Montague, in Buckingham, Northampton, and in Leicestershire shalt find Men well inclined to hear what thou command'st. And thou, brave Oxford, wondrous well beloved, In Oxfordshire shalt muster up thy friends. My sovereign, with the loving citizens, Like to his island girt in with the ocean, Or modest Dian circled with her nymphs, Shall rest in London till we come to him. Fair lords, take leave and stand not to reply. Farewell, my sovereign.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Farewell, my Hector, and my Troy's true hope.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: In sign of truth, I kiss your Highness' hand.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Well-minded Clarence, be thou fortunate.

dialogues.speaker: Montague
dialogues.line: Comfort, my lord; and so I take my leave.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: And thus  I seal my truth, and bid adieu.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Sweet Oxford, and my loving Montague, And all at once, once more a happy farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Farewell, sweet lords; let's meet at Coventry.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Here at the palace will I rest a while. Cousin of Exeter, what thinks your lordship? Methinks the power that Edward hath in field Should not be able to encounter mine.

dialogues.speaker: Exeter
dialogues.line: The doubt is that he will seduce the rest.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: That's not my fear; my meed hath got me fame. I have not stopped mine ears to their demands, Nor posted off their suits with slow delays; My pity hath been balm to heal their wounds, My mildness hath allayed their swelling griefs, My mercy dried their water-flowing tears. I have not been desirous of their wealth Nor much oppressed them with great subsidies, Nor forward of revenge, though they much erred. Then why should they love Edward more than me? No, Exeter, these graces challenge grace; And when the lion fawns upon the lamb, The lamb will never cease to follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Exeter
dialogues.line: Hark, hark, my lord, what shouts are these? Enter King Edward, Richard (Duke of Gloucester) and Soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Seize on the shame-faced Henry, bear him hence, And once again proclaim us King of England. You are the fount that makes small brooks to flow. Now stops thy spring; my sea shall suck them dry And swell so much the higher by their ebb. Hence with him to the Tower. Let him not speak. And, lords, towards Coventry bend we our course, Where peremptory Warwick now remains. The sun shines hot, and, if we use delay, Cold biting winter mars our hoped-for hay.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Away betimes, before his forces join, And take the great-grown traitor unawares. Brave warriors, march amain towards Coventry.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford? How far hence is thy lord, mine honest fellow? 1 MESSENGER. By this at Dunsmore, marching hitherward.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: How far off is our brother Montague? Where is the post that came from Montague? 2 MESSENGER. By this at Daintry, with a puissant troop.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Say, Somerville, what says my loving son? And, by thy guess, how nigh is Clarence now?

dialogues.speaker: Somerville
dialogues.line: At Southam I did leave him with his forces And do expect him here some two hours hence.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Then Clarence is at hand; I hear his drum.

dialogues.speaker: Somerville
dialogues.line: It is not his, my lord; here Southam lies. The drum your honour hears marcheth from Warwick.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Who should that be? Belike, unlooked-for friends.

dialogues.speaker: Somerville
dialogues.line: They are at hand, and you shall quickly know. March. Flourish. Enter King Edward, Richard (Duke of Gloucester) and Soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Go, trumpet, to the walls and sound a parle.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: See how the surly Warwick mans the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: O, unbid spite! Is sportful Edward come? Where slept our scouts, or how are they seduced, That we could hear no news of his repair?

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Now, Warwick, wilt thou ope the city gates, Speak gentle words and humbly bend thy knee? Call Edward King and at his hands beg mercy, And he shall pardon thee these outrages.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Nay, rather, wilt thou draw thy forces hence, Confess who set thee up and plucked thee down, Call Warwick patron and be penitent, And thou shalt still remain the Duke of York.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I thought, at least, he would have said the King; Or did he make the jest against his will?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Is not a dukedom, sir, a goodly gift?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Ay, by my faith, for a poor earl to give; I'll do thee service for so good a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: 'Twas I that gave the kingdom to thy brother.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Why, then, 'tis mine, if but by Warwick's gift.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Thou art no Atlas for so great a weight; And, weakling, Warwick takes his gift again; And Henry is my King, Warwick his subject.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: But Warwick's king is Edward's prisoner; And, gallant Warwick, do but answer this: What is the body when the head is off?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Alas, that Warwick had no more forecast, But, whiles he thought to steal the single ten, The king was slily fingered from the deck! You left poor Henry at the Bishop's palace, And ten to one you'll meet him in the Tower.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: 'Tis even so; yet you are Warwick still.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Come, Warwick, take the time; kneel down, kneel down. Nay, when? Strike now, or else the iron cools.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: I had rather chop this hand off at a blow And with the other fling it at thy face, Than bear so low a sail to strike to thee.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Sail how thou canst, have wind and tide thy friend, This hand, fast wound about thy coal-black hair, Shall, whiles thy head is warm and new cut off, Write in the dust this sentence with thy blood: "Wind-changing Warwick now can change no more."

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: O cheerful colours! See where Oxford comes!

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: The gates are open; let us enter too.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: So other foes may set upon our backs. Stand we in good array, for they no doubt Will issue out again and bid us battle; If not, the city being but of small defence, We'll quietly rouse the traitors in the same.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: O, welcome, Oxford, for we want thy help.

dialogues.speaker: Montague
dialogues.line: Montague, Montague, for Lancaster!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Thou and thy brother both shall buy this treason Even with the dearest blood your bodies bear.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: The harder matched, the greater victory. My mind presageth happy gain and conquest.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Somerset, Somerset, for Lancaster!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Two of thy name, both Dukes of Somerset, Have sold their lives unto the House of York; And thou shalt be the third if this sword hold. Enter George (Duke of Clarence) with drum and colours.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: And lo, where George of Clarence sweeps along, Of force enough to bid his brother battle; With whom an upright zeal to right prevails More than the nature of a brother's love. Come, Clarence, come; thou wilt if Warwick call.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: Father of Warwick, know you what this means? Look here, I throw my infamy at thee. I will not ruinate my father's house, Who gave his blood to lime the stones together, And set up Lancaster. Why, trowest thou, Warwick, That Clarence is so harsh, so blunt, unnatural, To bend the fatal instruments of war Against his brother and his lawful King? Perhaps thou wilt object my holy oath. To keep that oath were more impiety Than Jephthah's when he sacrificed his daughter. I am so sorry for my trespass made That, to deserve well at my brother's hands, I here proclaim myself thy mortal foe, With resolution, whereso'er I meet thee- As I will meet thee if thou stir abroad- To plague thee for thy foul misleading me. And so, proud-hearted Warwick, I defy thee, And to my brother turn my blushing cheeks. Pardon me, Edward, I will make amends. And, Richard, do not frown upon my faults, For I will henceforth be no more unconstant.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Now, welcome more, and ten times more beloved, Than if thou never hadst deserved our hate.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Welcome, good Clarence; this is brother-like.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: O passing traitor, perjured and unjust!

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: What, Warwick, wilt thou leave the town and fight? Or shall we beat the stones about thine ears?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Alas! I am not cooped here for defence! I will away towards Barnet presently And bid thee battle, Edward, if thou dar'st.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Yes, Warwick, Edward dares, and leads the way. Lords, to the field! Saint George and victory!

scenes.location: A Field of Battle near Barnet

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: So, lie thou there. Die thou, and die our fear, For Warwick was a bug that feared us all. Now, Montague, sit fast; I seek for thee, That Warwick's bones may keep thine company.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Ah, who is nigh? Come to me, friend or foe, And tell me who is victor, York or Warwick? Why ask I that? My mangled body shows, My blood, my want of strength, my sick heart shows That I must yield my body to the earth And, by my fall, the conquest to my foe. Thus yields the cedar to the axe's edge, Whose arms gave shelter to the princely eagle, Under whose shade the ramping lion slept, Whose top branch overpeered Jove's spreading tree, And kept low shrubs from winter's pow'rful wind. These eyes, that now are dimmed with death's black veil, Have been as piercing as the midday sun, To search the secret treasons of the world; The wrinkles in my brows, now filled with blood, Were likened oft to kingly sepulchres, For who lived King but I could dig his grave? And who durst smile when Warwick bent his brow? Lo, now my glory smeared in dust and blood! My parks, my walks, my manors that I had, Even now forsake me; and of all my lands Is nothing left me but my body's length. Why, what is pomp, rule, reign, but earth and dust? And live we how we can, yet die we must.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Ah, Warwick, Warwick, wert thou as we are, We might recover all our loss again. The Queen from France hath brought a puissant power; Even now we heard the news. Ah, couldst thou fly!

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Why, then I would not fly. Ah, Montague! If thou be there, sweet brother, take my hand And with thy lips keep in my soul awhile. Thou lov'st me not; for, brother, if thou didst, Thy tears would wash this cold congealed blood That glues my lips and will not let me speak. Come quickly, Montague, or I am dead.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Ah, Warwick, Montague hath breathed his last, And to the latest gasp cried out for Warwick, And said "Commend me to my valiant brother." And more he would have said, and more he spoke, Which sounded like a cannon in a vault, That mought not be distinguished; but at last I well might hear, delivered with a groan, "O farewell, Warwick!"

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Sweet rest his soul! Fly, lords, and save yourselves, For Warwick bids you all farewell, to meet in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: Away, away, to meet the Queen's great power!

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Thus far our fortune keeps an upward course, And we are graced with wreaths of victory. But in the midst of this bright-shining day, I spy a black, suspicious, threat'ning cloud That will encounter with our glorious sun Ere he attain his easeful western bed. I mean, my lords, those powers that the Queen Hath raised in Gallia have arrived our coast And, as we hear, march on to fight with us.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: A little gale will soon disperse that cloud And blow it to the source from whence it came; Thy very beams will dry those vapours up, For every cloud engenders not a storm.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: The Queen is valued thirty thousand strong, And Somerset, with Oxford, fled to her. If she have time to breathe, be well assured Her faction will be full as strong as ours.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: We are advertised by our loving friends That they do hold their course toward Tewkesbury. We, having now the best at Barnet field, Will thither straight, for willingness rids way; And, as we march, our strength will be augmented In every county as we go along. Strike up the drum! cry "Courage!" and away.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Great lords, wise men ne'er sit and wail their loss, But cheerly seek how to redress their harms. What though the mast be now blown overboard, The cable broke, the holding-anchor lost, And half our sailors swallowed in the flood? Yet lives our pilot still. Is 't meet that he Should leave the helm and, like a fearful lad, With tearful eyes add water to the sea And give more strength to that which hath too much, Whiles in his moan the ship splits on the rock, Which industry and courage might have saved? Ah, what a shame, ah, what a fault were this! Say Warwick was our anchor; what of that? And Montague our topmast; what of him? Our slaughtered friends the tackles; what of these? Why, is not Oxford here another anchor? And Somerset another goodly mast? The friends of France our shrouds and tacklings? And, though unskilful, why not Ned and I For once allowed the skilful pilot's charge? We will not from the helm to sit and weep, But keep our course, though the rough wind say no, From shelves and rocks that threaten us with wrack. As good to chide the waves as speak them fair. And what is Edward but a ruthless sea? What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit? And Richard but a ragged fatal rock? All these the enemies to our poor bark? Say you can swim: alas, 'tis but a while! Tread on the sand: why, there you quickly sink; Bestride the rock: the tide will wash you off, Or else you famish; that's a threefold death. This speak I, lords, to let you understand, If case some one of you would fly from us, That there's no hoped-for mercy with the brothers More than with ruthless waves, with sands, and rocks. Why, courage then! What cannot be avoided 'Twere childish weakness to lament or fear.

dialogues.speaker: Prince Edward
dialogues.line: Methinks a woman of this valiant spirit Should, if a coward heard her speak these words, Infuse his breast with magnanimity And make him, naked, foil a man at arms. I speak not this as doubting any here; For did I but suspect a fearful man, He should have leave to go away betimes, Lest in our need he might infect another And make him of the like spirit to himself. If any such be here, as God forbid! Let him depart before we need his help.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: Women and children of so high a courage, And warriors faint! Why, 'twere perpetual shame. O, brave young Prince, thy famous grandfather Doth live again in thee. Long mayst thou live To bear his image and renew his glories!

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: And he that will not fight for such a hope, Go home to bed and, like the owl by day, If he arise, be mocked and wondered at.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Thanks, gentle Somerset. Sweet Oxford, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Prince Edward
dialogues.line: And take his thanks that yet hath nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Prepare you, lords, for Edward is at hand Ready to fight; therefore be resolute.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: I thought no less. It is his policy To haste thus fast, to find us unprovided.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: But he's deceived; we are in readiness.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: This cheers my heart, to see your forwardness.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: Here pitch our battle; hence we will not budge.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Brave followers, yonder stands the thorny wood Which by the heaven's assistance and your strength Must by the roots be hewn up yet ere night. I need not add more fuel to your fire, For, well I wot, ye blaze to burn them out. Give signal to the fight, and to it, lords!

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Lords, knights, and gentlemen, what I should say My tears gainsay; for every word I speak Ye see I drink the water of my eye. Therefore, no more but this: Henry, your sovereign, Is prisoner to the foe, his state usurped, His realm a slaughter-house, his subjects slain, His statutes cancelled, and his treasure spent; And yonder is the wolf that makes this spoil. You fight in justice. Then, in God's name, lords, Be valiant and give signal to the fight.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Now here a period of tumultuous broils. Away with Oxford to Hames Castle straight. For Somerset, off with his guilty head. Go, bear them hence; I will not hear them speak.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: For my part, I'll not trouble thee with words.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Nor I, but stoop with patience to my fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: So part we sadly in this troublous world, To meet with joy in sweet Jerusalem.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Is proclamation made that who finds Edward Shall have a high reward, and he his life?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: It is, and lo where youthful Edward comes.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Bring forth the gallant; let us hear him speak. What, can so young a man begin to prick? Edward, what satisfaction canst thou make For bearing arms, for stirring up my subjects, And all the trouble thou hast turned me to?

dialogues.speaker: Prince Edward
dialogues.line: Speak like a subject, proud, ambitious York. Suppose that I am now my father's mouth; Resign thy chair, and where I stand kneel thou, Whilst I propose the selfsame words to thee Which, traitor, thou wouldst have me answer to.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Ah, thy father had been so resolved!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: That you might still have worn the petticoat And ne'er have stol'n the breech from Lancaster.

dialogues.speaker: Prince Edward
dialogues.line: Let Aesop fable in a winter's night; His currish riddle sorts not with this place.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: By heaven, brat, I'll plague you for that word.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Ay, thou wast born to be a plague to men.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: For God's sake, take away this captive scold.

dialogues.speaker: Prince Edward
dialogues.line: Nay, take away this scolding crookback rather.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Peace, wilful boy, or I will charm your tongue.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: Untutored lad, thou art too malapert.

dialogues.speaker: Prince Edward
dialogues.line: I know my duty; you are all undutiful. Lascivious Edward, and thou perjured George, And thou misshapen Dick, I tell ye all I am your better, traitors as ye are, And thou usurp'st my father's right and mine.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Take that, the likeness of this railer here.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Sprawl'st thou? Take that to end thy agony.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: And there's for twitting me with perjury.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: O, kill me too!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Marry, and shall.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Hold, Richard, hold; for we have done too much.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Why should she live to fill the world with words?

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: What, doth she swoon? Use means for her recovery.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Clarence, excuse me to the King my brother. I'll hence to London on a serious matter. Ere ye come there, be sure to hear some news.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: What? What?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: The Tower, the Tower!

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: O Ned, sweet Ned, speak to thy mother, boy. Canst thou not speak? O traitors, murderers! They that stabbed Caesar shed no blood at all, Did not offend, nor were not worthy blame, If this foul deed were by to equal it. He was a man; this, in respect, a child, And men ne'er spend their fury on a child. What's worse than murderer, that I may name it? No, no, my heart will burst an if I speak; And I will speak, that so my heart may burst. Butchers and villains, bloody cannibals! How sweet a plant have you untimely cropped! You have no children, butchers; if you had, The thought of them would have stirred up remorse. But if you ever chance to have a child, Look in his youth to have him so cut off As, deathsmen, you have rid this sweet young prince!

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Away with her; go bear her hence perforce.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Nay, never bear me hence, dispatch me here. Here sheathe thy sword; I'll pardon thee my death. What, wilt thou not? Then, Clarence, do it thou.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: By heaven, I will not do thee so much ease.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Good Clarence, do; sweet Clarence, do thou do it.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: Didst thou not hear me swear I would not do it?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Ay, but thou usest to forswear thyself. 'Twas sin before, but now 'tis charity. What, wilt thou not? Where is that devil's butcher, Richard, Hard-favoured Richard? Richard, where art thou? Thou art not here. Murder is thy alms-deed; Petitioners for blood thou ne'er putt'st back.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Away, I say! I charge ye, bear her hence.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: So come to you and yours as to this prince!

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Where's Richard gone?

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: To London all in post, and, as I guess, To make a bloody supper in the Tower.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: He's sudden if a thing comes in his head. Now march we hence. Discharge the common sort With pay and thanks, and let's away to London And see our gentle Queen how well she fares. By this, I hope, she hath a son for me.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Good day, my lord. What, at your book so hard?

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lord-my lord, I should say rather. 'Tis sin to flatter; "good" was little better: "Good Gloucester" and "good devil" were alike, And both preposterous; therefore, not "good lord".

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Sirrah, leave us to ourselves; we must confer.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: So flies the reckless shepherd from the wolf; So first the harmless sheep doth yield his fleece, And next his throat unto the butcher's knife. What scene of death hath Roscius now to act?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind; The thief doth fear each bush an officer.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: The bird that hath been limed in a bush With trembling wings misdoubteth every bush; And I, the hapless male to one sweet bird, Have now the fatal object in my eye Where my poor young was limed, was caught, and killed.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Why, what a peevish fool was that of Crete That taught his son the office of a fowl! And yet, for all his wings, the fool was drowned.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: I, Daedalus; my poor boy, Icarus; Thy father, Minos, that denied our course; The sun that seared the wings of my sweet boy, Thy brother Edward; and thyself, the sea Whose envious gulf did swallow up his life. Ah, kill me with thy weapon, not with words! My breast can better brook thy dagger's point Than can my ears that tragic history. But wherefore dost thou come? Is 't for my life?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Think'st thou I am an executioner?

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: A persecutor I am sure thou art. If murdering innocents be executing, Why, then thou art an executioner.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Thy son I killed for his presumption.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Hadst thou been killed when first thou didst presume, Thou hadst not lived to kill a son of mine. And thus I prophesy: that many a thousand Which now mistrust no parcel of my fear, And many an old man's sigh, and many a widow's, And many an orphan's water-standing eye, Men for their sons', wives for their husbands', Orphans for their parents' timeless death, Shall rue the hour that ever thou wast born. The owl shrieked at thy birth, an evil sign; The night-crow cried, aboding luckless time; Dogs howled, and hideous tempest shook down trees; The raven rooked her on the chimney's top, And chatt'ring pies in dismal discord sung; Thy mother felt more than a mother's pain, And yet brought forth less than a mother's hope, To wit, an indigested and deformed lump, Not like the fruit of such a goodly tree. Teeth hadst thou in thy head when thou wast born, To signify thou cam'st to bite the world; And, if the rest be true which I have heard, Thou cam'st-

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I'll hear no more. Die, prophet, in thy speech. For this, amongst the rest, was I ordained.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Ay, and for much more slaughter after this. O God, forgive my sins, and pardon thee!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: What, will the aspiring blood of Lancaster Sink in the ground? I thought it would have mounted. See how my sword weeps for the poor King's death. O, may such purple tears be always shed From those that wish the downfall of our house! If any spark of life be yet remaining, Down, down to hell; and say I sent thee thither- I that have neither pity, love, nor fear. Indeed, 'tis true that Henry told me of, For I have often heard my mother say I came into the world with my legs forward. Had I not reason, think ye, to make haste And seek their ruin that usurped our right? The midwife wondered, and the women cried "O, Jesus bless us, he is born with teeth!" And so I was, which plainly signified That I should snarl, and bite, and play the dog. Then, since the heavens have shaped my body so, Let hell make crooked my mind to answer it. I have no brother, I am like no brother; And this word "love," which greybeards call divine, Be resident in men like one another, And not in me. I am myself alone. Clarence, beware; thou keep'st me from the light, But I will sort a pitchy day for thee; For I will buzz abroad such prophecies That Edward shall be fearful of his life; And then, to purge his fear, I'll be thy death. King Henry and the Prince his son are gone; Clarence, thy turn is next, and then the rest, Counting myself but bad till I be best. I'll throw thy body in another room, And triumph, Henry, in thy day of doom.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Once more we sit in England's royal throne, Repurchased with the blood of enemies. What valiant foemen, like to autumn's corn, Have we mowed down in tops of all their pride! Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold renowned For hardy and undoubted champions; Two Cliffords, as the father and the son; And two Northumberlands; two braver men Ne'er spurred their coursers at the trumpet's sound; With them the two brave bears, Warwick and Montague, That in their chains fettered the kingly lion And made the forest tremble when they roared. Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat And made our footstool of security. Come hither, Bess, and let me kiss my boy. Young Ned, for thee thine uncles and myself Have in our armours watched the winter's night, Went all afoot in summer's scalding heat, That thou mightst repossess the crown in peace; And of our labours thou shalt reap the gain.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I'll blast his harvest, if your head were laid; For yet I am not looked on in the world. This shoulder was ordained so thick to heave, And heave it shall some weight or break my back. Work thou the way, and that shall execute.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Clarence and Gloucester, love my lovely Queen; And kiss your princely nephew, brothers both.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: The duty that I owe unto your Majesty I seal upon the lips of this sweet babe.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Thanks, noble Clarence; worthy brother, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: And, that I love the tree from whence thou sprang'st, Witness the loving kiss I give the fruit.  To say the truth, so Judas kissed his master And cried "All hail!" when as he meant all harm.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Now am I seated as my soul delights, Having my country's peace and brothers' loves.

dialogues.speaker: George
dialogues.line: What will your Grace have done with Margaret? Reignier, her father, to the King of France Hath pawned the Sicils and Jerusalem, And hither have they sent it for her ransom.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Away with her and waft her hence to France. And now what rests but that we spend the time With stately triumphs, mirthful comic shows, Such as befits the pleasure of the court? Sound drums and trumpets! Farewell, sour annoy! For here, I hope, begins our lasting joy.
